My statement on President Trump's Executive Order on Refugees:  “President Trump’s Executive order bars all travelers from seven mostly Muslim nations for at least 90 days, and it effectively prohibits Muslim refugees from anywhere in the world being resettled in the U.S. for a minimum of 120 days, and in case of Syrian refugees, indefinitely. This shuts the door to Muslims fleeing violence and persecution.  “Our nation has served as a beacon for those in desperate situations, and with the President’s Executive Order, that light is much dimmer today. The total ban of Syrian refugees, who are fleeing deplorable conditions and caught between the Assad regime and ISIS, is neither an effective national security strategy, nor reflective of our character as a nation. The Administration’s action fails to acknowledge the rigorous and lengthy process which currently takes between 18-24 months, and involves multiple Federal intelligence, security, and law enforcement agencies. At any time during the process, refugees cannot be resettled to the United States if U.S. security agencies cannot verify details, or if they cannot pass screenings. We can and must both fight terrorism and help those who seek to escape it. This Executive Order does neither.”  You can view the statement here:http://levin.house.gov/press-release/levin-statement-president-trump%E2%80%99s-executive-order-refugees

I’ve asked folks to share their stories about how the #AffordableCareAct has helped them live better, healthier lives. I want to share a particularly compelling story, coming from Kate from Ann Arbor.   Kate writes: “In September 2012, at age 24, I left my full-time job at a local nonprofit with great benefits to pursue a masters degree in social work. Frankly, I wasn't too worried - I had always been in good health. But, thanks to the ACA, I was able to go back on my parents' insurance plan, and I started classes in September. I was feeling tired and run down, with a nagging cough, but at 24 it was easy to chalk that up to balancing school and work. That December, I noticed a bump on my collarbone and several swollen lymph nodes.  Despite being sure that it was nothing, my friend convinced me to make an appointment with my doctor.  “It was stage 3 Hodgkin's lymphoma - a blood cancer. In one appointment, my life turned upside down, and soon I was facing biopsies, blood tests, and treatment planning. In January 2013, I began six months of chemotherapy. That June, my scans showed a great response to treatment - but there was still active cancer, so I went on to a month of radiation therapy. In November, I learned that I was finally in remission.   “What stands out to me most is that while I worried a lot that year, and I still worry today - about recurrence, long-term side effects, and survivorship - what I never had to worry about, thanks to the ACA, was being denied treatment for lack of resources or insurance. I didn't have to worry about the long term implications of my "pre-existing condition." No person, cancer patient or otherwise, should ever have to fear that the scariest time in their life could be made even harder by leaders who do not value health care as a basic human right.”  You can share a story of how the #AffordableCareAct has impacted the lives of you and your family here: http://bit.ly/2kk6Sv8

As of today, Title IX has been the law of the land for 45 years. Since its passage on June 23, 1972, this landmark law, which prohibits discrimination on the basis of sex in our education system, has helped our country take great leaps towards equality. Over these years, I have worked to help Title IX expand and thrive—and recently, to protect it from diminishment.  This week, I signed a letter to Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos urging her not to rescind Title IX guidelines that advise schools on how best to eliminate discrimination against LGBT students and on how to prevent cases of sexual assault in schools. These guidelines promote consistent, informed, and effective approaches to grave challenges students face. Removing them is a real setback in the fight for equality.  Title IX’s role in revolutionizing women’s inclusion in sports, in expansion of women’s roles in the workforce, in protection against sexual assault, and in advancing LGBT rights is a track record we should build upon, not tear down. As a member of Congress, I will continue to fight for Title IX’s place in the march towards equality.     http://digital.vpr.net/post/assessing-impact-45-years-title-ix#stream/0

Today’s news further illustrates how important it is to develop additional layers of defense to keep the carp out of Lake Michigan.   For these reasons, I am an original cosponsor of the Stop Asian Carp Now Act. This bill directs the Secretary of the Army Corps to release their study on the Brandon Road Lock and Dam, the “choke point” dam in the Chicago waterway system, that was ready for release in February but its release has been put on hold due to the Trump Administration. Releasing this study is imperative so local, state, and the federal government can work together with interested groups and fisheries to implement a long-term solution or keeping carp out of our beloved Great Lakes.

Your morning #ACA story:  You might have heard that the Senate is considering changes to the ACA. This bill would still be incredibly harmful for those on Medicaid, including expanded Medicaid or Healthy Michigan, like Lindsay from Hazel Park.   Lindsay writes: The ACA has impacted nearly everyone in my family. When I was 13, my mom decided to go back to school to get a degree as a Physician’s Assistant, to earn more money for our college educations and to buy a house (we had been living with my Grandma). When she went back to school we lost our insurance. If we had to see a dentist or a doctor my mom paid out of pocket. This meant that we really only sought care if it was absolutely essential. I’m currently a graduate student. I bought a policy in 2013 because my husband and I wanted to have a child. After my daughter was born, my family qualified for Medicaid under the expansion. I literally cannot express the peace of mind that I have because my daughter can access routine and emergency medical care because of the ACA and Medicaid expansion. #ProtectOurCare #ACAWorks

Your morning #ACA story:  One of the hallmarks of the ACA was providing affordable insurance to those who might not have had it before. This includes those whose employers do not offer health insurance, like Stefanie from Livonia.   Here’s more of Stefanie’s story: For my entire adult life, I have worked in the customer service industry. I've never worked for an employer who has offered healthcare coverage, so until the ACA was passed, I never had healthcare coverage. Through the ACA I was able to purchase a silver plan through Total Health Care.  In December of 2015, the apartment building in which I lived had a fire. I was trapped inside of the burning apartment building. I jumped, and was taken by ambulance to Beaumont Hospital with an open fracture of the left ankle, a shattered heel bone, and a broken back. I had three surgeries and months of therapies, all covered by my ACA plan. In October of 2016 I had a 3rd and final surgery on my foot. At this point, I had been out of work for almost a year, and I was covered by a Healthy Michigan plan for the remainder of 2016. I am currently covered under the Medicaid expansion. Without this critical healthcare coverage, I would have been saddled with over $700,000 in medical bills. I would be bankrupt. I might not have my left foot, and I may not have been able to relearn how to walk. #ProtectOurCare #ACAWorks

Your morning #ACA story:  Rachel from Grosse Pointe Farms: Our beautiful baby girl was born in Detroit, Michigan on July 8, 2015. On July 9th, one of the most frightening days of our lives, she had to be transported via ambulance from our hospital to the Children's Hospital NICU to prepare for emergency heart surgery. Three lengthy hospital stays and as many open heart surgeries later, our beautiful baby is a healthy and thriving toddler with a St. Jude mechanical mitral valve. She will need to take coumadin (blood thinner) her whole life, take sildenafil for blood pressure, and avoid contact sports. Her hospital stays and medications totaled well over a million dollars - closer to two. Without Obamacare, our family would be bankrupt, worrying about how to pay for her life saving medications. I cannot express how stressful and gut-wrenching a time this was for my family. I am thankful every day for Obamacare. #ProtectOurCare #ACAWorks

Your morning #ACA story:  So many of the protections in the ACA have helped families ensure young adults have quality health care. Here’s the story of Ed, who lives in Farmington Hills, and his family:  In May 2015, our youngest son Alex, then 22 years old, was diagnosed with an aggressive form of Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma. To try to save his life, it was necessary to start aggressive treatment immediately.  Alex had just recently graduated from Eastern Michigan University and had not yet secured a job with health benefits. Fortunately, because of the Affordable Care Act, we were able to maintain Alex on the health plan my wife. If it wasn’t for the ACA, Alex could not have stayed on her policy and he could not have afforded to secure his own health coverage.  After a series of treatments, Alex received his “no evidence of cancer” news in October 2015. Since that time, he has needed regular testing to confirm that the cancer has not come back and he has been hospitalized twice for intestinal bowel blockages related to the impact of the chemotherapy treatments.  To date, his medical costs are approaching $400,000 over the last year and a half…and he is only 24 years old. Up to now, except for approximately $175 of co-pays and the approximately $600 per month that my wife must contribute toward her healthcare insurance, all of these charges have been covered by our health insurance.  Read more of Ed’s story  here: http://www.theoaklandpress.com/general-news/20170706/families-affected-by-aca-speak-in-royal-oak-against-its-repeal  #ProtectOurCare #ACAWorks

Your morning #ACA story:  Kay and Jay from Clinton Twp.: We were always fortunate to always have had good insurance for our family. That was until my husband, a computer analyst, was downsized from his job. Now we would face our retirement years without insurance if not for the ACA. So often you hear about “pre-existing conditions” as if they are all multi-million dollar expenditures. I am perfectly healthy, but about 20 years ago I had a small malignant melanoma removed; as a cancer survivor, I am now uninsurable. My husband has minor illnesses; all would be considered “pre-existing” under any other kind of health care. We have 3 children. All of them are healthy - except they have anaphylactic food allergies, and carry Epi-Pens - so they all have pre-existing conditions. Being in a high-risk pool for our entire family would probably be so expensive it would wipe us out. If we didn’t have insurance, a car crash, a major illness, anything — we could lose everything we have, everything we’ve built over a lifetime. Our oldest goes off to medical school next year. With the ACA, she can still be covered while she learns her profession, even with her chronic condition. She deserves a chance to become what she is capable of. She deserves to live. So do we. People sickening and dying for want of health insurance is a shame upon America. We’ve done better, and we can’t go back to those days. #ProtectOurCare #ACAWorks

Your morning #ACA story:  Raye, from Roseville: About the ACA in my family’s life… The timing was perfect for me when the ACA was first passed into law in 2010: I was in my 20th year of teaching as an adjunct instructor at Wayne State, and there was still NO health coverage for adjunct faculty at that point. Because I was carrying a high-deductible, catastrophic coverage only type policy, I had been putting off taking care of an increasingly painful problem with my back that finally landed me in the hospital in October 2011 for emergency surgery. By then, thankfully, I had an established ACA policy through Humana, and while there was still a $5,000 deductible to pay, it was much more do-able than it would have been before the ACA. I would have simply been disabled and unable to continue teaching if I didn’t have that surgery.   Since that time I have transitioned over to Medicare, but my sons and their families are now very vulnerable to any repeal or replace actions the GOP might pursue. I hope that Congress will drop the politics, stop using healthcare as a pretext for tax cuts, and start caring about the actual health and wellbeing of Americans. What is so difficult about that? #ProtectOurCare #ACAWorks

Your morning #ACA story:  Sue from Warren writes: My husband spent 22 years in the Air Force before retiring. Because of that we have coverage under the health plan they offer to retirees, Tricare Prime. It is an excellent program with low premiums for both of us. However, my daughter lost this coverage when she turned 21. The reason is that Tricare is an "entitlement program.” It is not "health insurance", so she could not be covered until the age of 26 like all other parents can do under the ACA guidelines. She has a pre-existing health condition, as well as being a woman. I signed her up for an ACA plan through the marketplace. The premiums aren't that high (about $300 a month)...that is less than I paid when I had healthcare through my employer for a much lower coverage plan. If the protections afforded by the ACA (no lifetime limits, no exclusion of pre-existing conditions) are removed, she will have to find insurance as a single person. She has no full time job and is attending school for a career she has not decided on yet. We are fortunate that she has no serious conditions such as diabetes or cancer. But what if she did get those? What would we do? My husband and I will be retiring in about 4 years from our jobs. We will then be on Medicare so we have our own concerns with that. But this is about the ACA and the other improvements made to overall healthcare plans that may disappear. #ProtectOurCare #ACAWorks

Your morning #ACA story:  Rebecca from Royal Oak: The Medicaid expansion saved me when I was having relapses with my MS which, required hospitalization. Currently I am on Medicare and fear that if my MS progresses to where I have to go into Long Term care, I will be lost without Medicaid due to my low income. If the administration takes away Medicare for people on SSDI I will also suffer but I am prepared to stop taking all of my medications that have helped to stave off further disability progression. #ProtectOurCare #ACAWorks

Your morning #ACA story:  Abby from Birmingham: I live in Birmingham with my husband and two daughters. I am a writer. We get our insurance through the ACA exchange - we do not qualify for subsidies. I have some pre-existing conditions that are well managed (thyroid deficiency). My younger daughter, age 10, has asthma which is also well-controlled thanks to daily inhaler therapy and a rescue inhaler if she needs it. We do not receive any subsidies for our coverage, and we do have substantial out-of-pocket costs, but nevertheless I feel protected by the ACA since there is an out-of-pocket maximum and we can't be discriminated against due to pre-existing conditions. The ACA is imperfect, but it's an improvement over what came before it, which was NO consumer protections. If the GOP thinks it has a better plan that is equally compassionate, then I'm listening, but we should not repeal the ACA unless & until the GOP presents a better plan. I do not believe in throwing sick people under the bus or "repeal and see what happens." It is morally wrong to play with people's lives like that, and that is not the kind of country we should be. #ProtectOurCare #ACAWorks

When President Roosevelt signed the Social Security Act into law on this date in 1935, the US was in the depths of the Great Depression, and Americans recognized that something must be done to help those in need and unable to work - the poor, the sick, and the elderly. Programs created by the Social Security Act have done just that for these 82 years.   But President Trump has requested $72 billion in cuts to Social Security programs that assist Americans with disabilities and families struggling with poverty. It is now the responsibility of Congress to reject these senseless cuts. I urge my colleagues in the House of Representatives to keep this classic FDR quote in mind as they draft the Fiscal Year 2018 budget: "The test of our progress is not whether we add more to the abundance of those who have much; it is whether we provide enough for those who have little."

Many of you may remember the story of Ryan White, a high school student from Indiana who was told he could not return to school after being diagnosed with HIV -- It was the mid-1980s, and the disease was fiercely stigmatized. But Ryan did not let the hostility he faced from his own community dampen his spirits. He gained nationwide recognition for his perseverance, helping to transform national attitudes about HIV/AIDS. For that reason, the Ryan White CARE Act bears his name. This landmark legislation, signed on today’s date in 1990, helps to provide care for low-income, uninsured, and under-insured HIV/AIDS patients in the United States.   In remembrance of Ryan’s courage I express my unwavering support for HIV/AIDS patients across the world.

Today marks 101 years of the National Park Service protecting our National Parks and ensuring they are accessible to the public. I usually spend the Park Service’s anniversary musing about my favorite natural monuments in America, but this year my attention is occupied by more sinister issues. I’m concerned that President Trump’s budget request for Fiscal Year 2018 makes deep cuts to the Park Service’s budget, and that his Secretary of the Interior, Ryan Zinke, is more concerned with exploiting public lands for resources than with protecting them. Secretary Zinke has claimed inspiration from Theodore Roosevelt, the President we most associate with conservation of the nation’s natural wonders. I encourage Secretary Zinke to take a hard look at his plans to shrink, deregulate, drill, and mine federal land, and ask himself what Teddy would do.

On this date in 1964, President Lyndon Johnson signed the Food Stamp Act, solidifying the place of the Food Stamp Program (now known as SNAP) in federal law. Though federal food assistance programs have changed in name and in policy many times since then, the founding principle holds steady -- nobody in this country should be allowed to go hungry.   But the Trump Administration does not appear to share this value. In his Fiscal Year 2018 budget request, President Trump proposed cutting SNAP by $191 billion over a ten-year period. If enacted, these cuts would affect the nearly 200,000 citizens of Oakland and Macomb Counties and the 43 million Americans nationwide who receive assistance from SNAP. There’s no excuse for taking food off the tables of American families in need.

Today I introduced a resolution with Reps. Marcy Kaptur (D-OH), Andy Harris (R-MD), and Brian Fitzpatrick (R-MD) commemorating the 85th anniversary of the Ukraine Holodomor Famine-Genocide.   The resolution honors the estimated seven to 10 million Ukrainian people who perished at the will of the totalitarian Stalinist government of the former Soviet Union, which perpetrated a premeditated famine in the winter of 1932-1933 in Ukraine in a concerted effort to break the nation's resistance to communist occupation. I am happy to share with you that today, Leader Pelosi, Speaker Ryan, and Leader McConnell dedicated a commemorative chair in honor of American prisoners of war and servicemen and women missing in action. The 1850s, hand-carved oak chair will be placed in Emancipation Hall of the United States Capitol Visitor Center.   Commemorative chairs have been unveiled throughout the country to serve as a reminder of America’s servicemen and women held prisoner or missing in action. This was a fitting dedication, coming just a few days prior to Veterans Day.

The Republican tax bill picks winners and losers – the big winners are the very wealthy and some corporations, and the losers are the middle class and those who aspire to it, and the rest of America who will be forced to pay for the bill’s massive debt for years to come. While the GOP bill gives the very wealthy enormous tax breaks, it actually raises taxes on tens of millions of middle-class families by eliminating the personal exemption and deductions for medical expenses, for full state and local taxes, and for educational needs. Speaker Ryan has said the bill is focused on the middle class, but that is simply not true. It’s really the opposite: it’s a bill built for millionaires. And the process used to consider it has been driven by desperation, rather than deliberation.   The more the American people learn about the Republican tax bill, the more they will reject it, just as every Democrat did today on the Committee on Ways and Means. Yesterday, I joined with other House Democrats requesting the FCC Chairman delay the vote on this issue, and am a cosponsor on HR 4585 – Save Net Neutrality Act. Be assured I will continue to stand for #netneutrality.
